Satterfield to questions submitted for the record by: The Honorable Eliot L. Engel, a Representative in Congress from the State of New York........................................ 62 The Honorable Brad Sherman, a Representative in Congress from the State of California...................................... 68 The Honorable Ted Lieu, a Representative in Congress from the State of California.......................................... 71 </option> <Doc-title>U.S. POLICY TOWARD A TURBULENT MIDDLE EAST</Doc-title> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="">Washington, DC.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker=""> The committee met, pursuant to notice, at 10 o'clock a.m., in room 2172 Rayburn House Office Building, Hon. Edward Royce (chairman of the committee) presiding. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Chairman Royce">This hearing will come to order.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Chairman Royce">In announcing military strikes against Syria last week, the President made clear the people of the Middle East must shape their own destiny.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Chairman Royce">He's right. But that doesn't mean that we don't have vital national interests in the region or a reason to promote stability, tolerance, and respect for human rights.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Chairman Royce">The U.S. and our allies were justified in taking limited military action against Bashar al-Assad. We took that action in response to his barbaric use of chemical weapons.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Chairman Royce">Hopefully, the Syrian dictator gets the message. If not, I have no doubt there will be more military strikes. The world has enough security challenges without the breakdown of the 100-year norm against the use of chemical weapons.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Chairman Royce">That said, military force cannot be the only means of responding to these atrocities. We need a strategy to get a political solution, one that moves beyond Assad to secure a lasting peace.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Chairman Royce">The previous administration did not have one. That's part of the reason why we're confronting this crisis today. The stakes in Syria are high. This chaos goes far beyond its borders, threatening allies and partners.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Chairman Royce">And I again commend Ranking Member Engel for his steadfast, years-long commitment to addressing this conflict.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Chairman Royce">There is no excuse for the Senate's failure to act on the Caesar Syria Civilian Protection Act. This bill, passed twice unanimously by the House, would make those supporting Assad's killing machine, and its barrel bombs and gas attacks, pay a real cost.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Chairman Royce">The committee also recently passed the No Assistance for Assad Act, which prohibits the regime and prohibits its allies from profiting from any reconstruction.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Chairman Royce">Both these bills would give our diplomats real leverage. If the U.S. isn't engaged in the Middle East, Iran will certainly take advantage.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Chairman Royce">Tehran is already aggressive and capable, as this committee has highlighted. The regime is using its bolstered position from a windfall of cash from the nuclear deal to help Hezbollah amass missiles along Israel's borders.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Chairman Royce">They are seeking, obviously, to establish a land bridge across Syria to Israel's doorstep and they are moving fighters and weapons across that land bridge to new bases on Israel's borders.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Chairman Royce">This is shoring up Assad, yes, and it is also threatening our troops that are fighting ISIS. And remember, Iran is also fueling the humanitarian disaster in Yemen with its support for the Houthis. Our closest partner in the region, Israel, is increasingly threatened by Iranian expansion but so are our other U.S. friends and allies in the region.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Chairman Royce">The Iran nuclear deal has serious flaws so let me speak to this for a moment. This committee has closely examined them. The administration is rightly working to address Iran's ballistic missiles, to strengthen inspections, and to fix the deal's sunset problem.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Chairman Royce">The British, the French, and the Germans need to stand with us. Meanwhile, the list of the region's other challenges is long. Our relationship with NATO ally Turkey is strained as never before. Its military offensive against the Kurds in Syria, frankly, has benefitted ISIS.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Chairman Royce">The Kurdish Syrian Democratic Forces we back now have to divert their operations from the offensives they were taking against ISIS to defensive actions, defending themselves from Turkish military attacks.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Chairman Royce">Turkey's increasing engagement with Russia and Iran is very concerning.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Chairman Royce">In Libya, radical jihadists remain strong. Neighboring Egypt is a critical partner in the fight against ISIS and should be supported, but its repression of civil society risks backfiring, and Hamas terrorists are inciting violence in Gaza.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Chairman Royce">As tempting as it is to say enough and retreat to our shores, smart, focused, and a determined engagement in the Middle East must be our approach. We need to talk strategy with the administration today about the Middle East and we appreciate them being here with the committee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Chairman Royce"> And I will now turn to the ranking member for his comments. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Engel</speaker> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Engel">Thank you, Mr. Chairman, for calling this hearing. To our witnesses, welcome to the Foreign Affairs Committee and thank you for your service.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Mr. Engel">Thank you, Mr. Mitchell, for being here today and it's good to see you again. I appreciate the excellent work you're doing.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Mr. Engel">Ambassador Satterfield, our first work on Syria reaches back about 15 years or so, so I appreciate your service as well.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Mr. Engel">Still, I wish we had a permanent Assistant Secretary in place. Nearly 15 months into this administration the White House only sent a nomination to the Senate last week.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. Engel">Syria has been a larger focus of mine. Many years ago--I think it was more than 15--Ileana Ros-Lehtinen and I introduced the Syria Accountability Act, which was passed into law with bipartisan support.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Engel">So we have a huge number of concerns about the Middle East. But today I am going to focus on Syria.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Engel">It's a shame that it takes a chemical weapons attack to grab the world's attention when it comes to Syria. After all, the vast majority of Assad's \1/2\ million victims didn't meet their ends in a chemical attack. It often wasn't sarin or chlorine that drove millions more from their homes.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Engel">For those who have lost love ones in these 7 years of brutal slaughter, the pain and the grief are no different whether they died in a chemical attack or in a hospital that was leveled to the ground or in a crowded street when a barrel bomb detonated.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Engel">Assad's a murderer, a butcher. His brutality is sickening and it goes on every day. Yet, I want to be clear. Assad's most recent use of chemical weapons is an abhorrent crime that demanded immediate consequences.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Mr. Engel">Late last week, the United States, the United Kingdom, and France acted together to dole out these consequences. The use of the weapons cannot stand and whoever would use them and whoever would support those who do cannot go unpunished.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Mr. Engel">But I want to be equally clear. If the administration plans ongoing military action, Congress must first authorize it or prevent it. Even under the most generous interpretation of the War Powers Resolution, the 60-day clock started ticking when the President notified Congress of the attack.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="35" speaker="Mr. Engel">Now, if anyone hear feels a sense of deja vu, you're not alone. A year ago, we were debating the same issue. Assad uses chemical weapons, the United States fires off some missiles, but the killing still continues.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="36" speaker="Mr. Engel">Why is history repeating itself? Mainly because the administration seems to have no strategy for dealing with the crisis in Syria. That's why regardless of what happens next we need to hear from the administration.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="37" speaker="Mr. Engel">Even if the President intends for last week's air strike to be another one-off response, the White House is still past due in laying out its strategy for Syria to Congress and the American people.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="38" speaker="Mr. Engel">As part of last year's defense authorization bill, we require the White House to come to us with a strategy by February 1st. That deadline has come and gone. I hope you'll tell us today if the strategy will be sent to Capitol Hill without any more delay.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="39" speaker="Mr. Engel">The incoherence is plain to see. Over the last year, the President has publicly disagreed with his top advisors about our path forward in Syria and is off-the-cuff remarks about leaving Syria and reckless rhetoric have at times emboldened Assad.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="40" speaker="Mr. Engel">Just prior to last year's chemical weapons attack, the President said we would have to accept Assad as a fact of life, and shortly before the most recent attack the President suggested a precipitous withdrawal from Syria.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="41" speaker="Mr. Engel">Rather than forming the policy that would help to resolve this crisis, I feel that the President has only made it worse. I am not holding my breath, but I continue to hope that the administration will bring us a plan that will push for an end to violence that will ease a political transition and that will help lay the groundwork for a future for Syria in which Bashar- al Assad has no role whatsoever.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="42" speaker="Mr. Engel">This is certainly no easy task and I'd be the first one to acknowledge that the previous administration should have done more.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="43" speaker="Mr. Engel">But there are still plenty of good ideas to help craft a policy like this. In fact, as the chairman mentioned, I've introduced two bills that I think would move us toward those goals.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="44" speaker="Mr. Engel">The Caesar Syria Civilian Protection Act passed the House unanimously last year. It started with bipartisan good work, as usual, from this committee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="45" speaker="Mr. Engel">This bill would crack down on Assad's enablers, namely Moscow and Tehran, who serve as lifelines to the barbaric regime.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="46" speaker="Mr. Engel">I have to say after the President personally overrode his own administration's plan to sanction Russia for its support of Assad, I think this bill is needed now more than ever.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="47" speaker="Mr. Engel">I hope the Senate will act on it soon. The other bill, as the chairman mentioned, is my No Assistance for Assad Act, which I introduced with Mr. Kinzinger and which this committee voted to advance a few weeks ago.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="48" speaker="Mr. Engel">This bill would restrict reconstruction funding for any area still controlled by Assad. One bill would help end the violence now. The other would make sure that when this crisis has ended no American tax dollars are going to help Assad cling to power.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="49" speaker="Mr. Engel">We cannot overstate the scope of the tragedy in Syria. Assad has the blood of hundreds of thousands of innocent Syrian men, women, and children on his hands.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="50" speaker="Mr. Engel">That this catastrophe has been allowed to go on for so long is a global failure that will leave a black mark on this era of human history. But we cannot throw up our hands in resignation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="51" speaker="Mr. Engel">If America is to remain a leader on the global stage, we must continue working to end the bloodshed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="52" speaker="Mr. Engel">I again thank our witnesses. I thank the chairman. I look forward to hearing how the administration intends to tackle this problem and the range of other challenges with which we are challenging in the Middle East.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="53" speaker="Mr. Engel"> Thank you, Mr. Chairman. I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="54" speaker="Chairman Royce">Thank you, Mr. Engel.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="55" speaker="Chairman Royce">So this morning we are pleased to welcome David Satterfield. He's Acting Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern Affairs, and Wess Mitchell is Assistant Secretary of State for European and Eurasian Affairs.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="56" speaker="Chairman Royce">Mr. Satterfield served in many senior positions within the department including as U.S. Ambassador to Lebanon, as Chief of Mission in Cairo, and Deputy Chief of Mission in Iraq.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="57" speaker="Chairman Royce">Dr. Mitchell, prior to his current position at the State Department, was the co-founder and president and CEO of the Center for European Policy Analysis and we appreciate them being here with us today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="58" speaker="Chairman Royce">Without objection, gentlemen, your full prepared statements will be made part of the record. Members here will have 5 calendar days to submit any statements or questions to you or any extraneous material for the record.</paragraph>
Hearing.Statement: <opening>STATEMENT OF THE HONORABLE DAVID M. SATTERFIELD, ACTING</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="THE HONORABLE DAVID M. SATTERFIELD"> So if you would, Mr. Satterfield, please summarize your remarks and after the 5 minutes we will go to Mr. Mitchell and then to the questions. ASSISTANT SECRETARY, BUREAU OF NEAR EASTERN AFFAIRS, U.S. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Satterfield</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">Thank you very much, Chairman Royce, Ranking Member Engel, members of the committee. I appreciate the opportunity for me, my colleague, Assistant Secretary Mitchell, to testify.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">From the Arab Spring in 2011 to the current civil wars in Syria and Yemen, the rise and fall of ISIS' so-called caliphate, no one would argue the many significant challenges the United States and our allies face in the region.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">However, I want to say at the beginning in many places the U.S. has made positive strides. We are supporting the growth of a nascent democracy in Tunisia.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">Economically, the region continues to support and we aggressively pursue American opportunities for business that generate American jobs.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">We have supported billions of dollars of sales to our partners in the Gulf, power generation solutions in Libya, Algeria, and Iraq, major sales of locomotives and other power sources in Egypt, and we have made significant dramatic progress against ISIS.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">However, this said, we are not blind to the continuing issues in the region and the U.S. is taking all possible steps to find solutions to this region's enduring challenges.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">On April 7th, after weeks of heavy Syrian and Russian bombardment on the people of Douma and adjacent areas, the regime deployed chemical weapons, killing dozens and injuring hundreds of innocent men, women, and children.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">On April 13th, the militaries of the United States, France, and the United Kingdom executed strikes on three chemical weapons facilities in Syria.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">Russia has failed to live up to its guarantee in regards to the 2013 framework agreement that Syria would cease all use of chemical weapons and fully declare its entire stockpile for verifiable destruction, and Iran acts malignly in Syria and through Syria, pouring resources and forces to support Assad and advance its regional ambitions including in Lebanon.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">The targeted military action by the U.S., France, and the U.K. was a measure to deter and prevent Syria's illegal and unacceptable use of chemical weapons.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">This sends, we hope, a positive and powerful message to the Syrian regime, Russia, Iran, and the international community that chemical weapons will not be tolerated and there will be real consequences for their use.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">While preventing the use of chemical weapons in Syria is our immediate concern, the administration's priority remains the defeat of ISIS. ISIS has lost nearly all of the territory it once controlled in Iraq in Syria. But the fight in Syria still has to be pursued to its conclusion.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">More broadly, the United States supports a unified and territorially whole Syria. This objective is served by U.S. support for the U.N.-led Geneva political process established by U.N. Security Council Resolution 2254 in which process the U.S. believes strongly that representatives of all Syrians including all its Kurdish components should fully participate.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">Our strategic partnership with Iraq including the Kurdistan region remains essential to ensuring the goal of a lasting defeat of ISIS and encountering Iran's malign influence in the region.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">The Iraqi Government is stabilizing communities including minority communities that suffered greatly from ISIS and now we are beginning private sector-led investment-driven reconstruction.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">On May 12th, all Iraqis, including Iraqi Kurds, will participate in parliamentary elections, the country's fourth since 2005.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">Iran's malign influence in the region continues to threaten our allies such as Jordan and Israel, and feeds violent conflicts in Syria and Yemen through Iran Revolutionary Guard Corps facilitation and work.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">The Houthis have repeatedly used in Yemen Iranian ballistic missile and cruise missile technology to threaten Saudi Arabia, including over 80,000 U.S. citizens in that country.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">U.S. military support for the Saudi-led coalition in Yemen serves a clear purpose--to reinforce Saudi and Emirati action on behalf of the Yemeni Government in the face of intensified Houthi threats and to expand the capability of our Gulf partners to push back themselves against Iran's destabilizing actions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">We all agree, as does the Congress, that the humanitarian crisis in Yemen is unacceptable. Last month, the Governments of Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates provided $1 billion to Yemen's humanitarian response appeal, and this complements the U.S. Government pledge of $87 million and more than $854 million contributed since beginning of fiscal year 2017.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">The Iranian regime is taking advantage, as I said, of regional conflict and instability to expand its influence and threaten its neighbors. We remain focused on neutralizing Iran's influence, particularly its support for terror and militance, cyber warfare, ballistic missiles, and use of proxy forces.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">Mr. Chairman, Ranking Member, members of the committee, the Middle East is a complex landscape and the people in the Middle East deserve an end to violence, hunger, and uncertainty.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Satterfield">We are working with our allies inside and outside the region to find solutions.</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Mr. Satterfield follows:][GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT]</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Mr. Satterfield ">Thank you for the opportunity to testify and I welcome the opportunity to respond to your questions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Satterfield ">[GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT]</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Satterfield "> ---------- </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Chairman Royce">Thank you, Ambassador Satterfield.</paragraph>

<opening>STATEMENT OF THE HONORABLE A. WESS MITCHELL, ASSISTANT</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="THE HONORABLE A. WESS MITCHELL"> Dr. Mitchell. SECRETARY, BUREAU OF EUROPEAN AND EURASIAN AFFAIRS, U.S. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Mitchell</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Mitchell">Chairman Royce, Ranking Member Engel, distinguished members of the committee, thank you for the opportunity to appear before you. It's an honor to represent the State Department's Bureau of European and Eurasian Affairs in this hearing.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Mitchell">In my comments today, I will focus on the strategic dimension of the conflict in Syria as it relates to the work of our bureau and, specifically, to the part played by the Republic of Turkey and the Russian Federation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Mitchell">America's goals in Syria have been to defeat ISIS, to see a Syria that is unified and stable emerge from the rubble of this conflict, and to prevent Iran, a power that aids and abets Hezbollah and that seeks the destruction of the state of Israel, from extending its malign influence in the region.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Mitchell">Let us assess Turkey and Russia as they relate to these goals. Turkey is a 66-year member of the NATO Alliance and member of the Defeat ISIS Coalition.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Mitchell">It has suffered more casualties from terrorism than any other ally and hosts 3.5 million Syrian refugees. It supports the coalition through the use of Incirlik Air Base, through its commitment of Turkish military forces against ISIS on the ground in Dabiq and Al-Bab, and through close intelligence cooperation with the United States and other allies.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Mitchell">Turkey is publicly committed to a political resolution in Syria that accords with U.N. Security Council Resolution 2254.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Mitchell">Turkey has a vested strategic interest in checking the spread of Iranian influence and in having a safe and stable border with Syria. Despite these shared interests, Turkey lately has increased its engagement with Russia and Iran.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Mitchell">Ankara has sought to assure us that it sees this cooperation as a necessary stepping stone toward progress in the Geneva process.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Mitchell">But the ease with which Turkey brokered arrangements with the Russian military to facilitate the launch of its Operation Olive Branch in Afrin district, arrangements to which America was not privy, is gravely concerning.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Mitchell">Ankara claims to have agreed to purchase a Russian S-400 missile system, which could potentially lead to sanctions under Section 231 of CAATSA and adversely impact Turkey's participation in the F-35 program.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Mitchell">It is in the American national interest to see Turkey remain strategically and politically aligned with the West. Our policy has been to combine close engagement with clear messaging that the United States will actively defend our interests.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Mitchell">In the context of Syria, we have engaged in high-level interagency discussions both to address legitimate Turkish security concerns and to avoid inadvertent collisions between our forces.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Mitchell">These conversations are ongoing. Moving forward, our aim is to enlist Turkey as a more active ally in supporting the Geneva process, the defeat of ISIS, and stabilization in Syria, as well as a long-term factor in thwarting expansion by Russia and Iran, as outlined in the national security strategy and national defense strategy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Mitchell">Let us now turn to Russia. It is hard to see how Russia shares any of America's strategic goals in Syria.
